issues.description: Solution's client PersonController.addPerson uses a synchronous/blocking WebClient call (.block()) while the problem statement explicitly requires that HTTP requests be performed asynchronously. The NoteController (template and solution) uses non-blocking reactive calls with subscribe(), showing the intended pattern. This mismatch between the stated requirement and the solution implementation can confuse students about the required asynchronous design and may teach an undesirable synchronous workaround.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's PersonController.addPerson follow the same non-blocking reactive pattern used by NoteController: do not call .block(). Instead retrieve the response as a Mono<Person> and subscribe to it, updating the internal persons list inside the subscribe callback (e.g. .retrieve().bodyToMono(Person.class).onErrorStop().subscribe(newPerson -> { persons.add(newPerson); personsConsumer.accept(persons); })). Remove the blocking call and the 'ARCHITECTURAL VIOLATION' synchronous implementation so the solution aligns with the asynchronous requirement in the problem statement.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, controller description) says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter... This consumer takes the internal list of persons as a parameter", which mixes the Note type into the description for PersonController. The template and solution PersonController method signatures use Consumer<List<Person>>. This type/name mismatch in the problem text (List<Note> vs List<Person>) is an unintended identifier/typing inconsistency that can confuse students about the expected callback type for PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods and their callback parameter. This aligns the description with the template and solution signatures and avoids confusion.
